title: Erdős Problem #144: Propinquity of Divisors
description: The density of integers with two divisors d₁ < d₂ < 2d₁ exists and equals 1. SOLVED by Maier-Tenenbaum (1984), who proved the stronger version for any c > 1. The threshold β* = log 3 - 1 separates density 1 from density 0.

overview.historicalContext: This problem asks about the 'propinquity' (closeness) of divisors. Erdős posed it in 1979, asking whether almost all integers have two divisors within a factor of 2 of each other. He initially claimed a proof in 1964 but retracted it in 1979 with Hall. The complete solution came from Maier and Tenenbaum in 1984, who also established the precise threshold β* = log 3 - 1 for the refined version. Tenenbaum reported receiving $650, more than the advertised $250 prize.
overview.problemStatement: Prove that the density of integers n which have two divisors d₁, d₂ with d₁ < d₂ < 2d₁ exists and equals 1. The stronger version asks for any constant c > 1 instead of 2.
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization captures the main theorem by Maier-Tenenbaum and the phase transition at β* = log 3 - 1. For β < β*, almost all integers have (β)-close divisors; for β > β*, almost none do. The proof uses probabilistic number theory, divisor distribution theory, and moment calculations.
keyInsights: Prime powers have no close divisors (consecutive divisors differ by factor p ≥ 2)
Most integers have many prime factors, causing divisors to cluster
The critical threshold β* = log 3 - 1 ≈ 0.0986 governs the phase transition
Erdős's 1964 proof was flawed but the conjecture was correct
The Erdős-Kac theorem (normal distribution of prime factors) underlies the result

sections.title: Part 1: Basic Definitions
sections.summary: Defines natural density, the close divisors property (d₁ < d₂ < 2d₁), the c-close divisors property for any c > 1, and the corresponding sets of integers.

sections.title: Part 2: The Main Theorem
sections.summary: States the Erdős Problem #144 conjecture (density = 1) and the Maier-Tenenbaum theorem proving it, including the strong version for arbitrary c > 1.

sections.title: Part 3: The Threshold β = log 3 - 1
sections.summary: Introduces the critical exponent β* = log 3 - 1, the refined close divisors property, and the phase transition: density 1 for β < β*, density 0 for β > β*. Proved phase_transition theorem.

sections.title: Part 4: Examples and Intuition
sections.summary: Concrete examples showing prime powers fail the test, while integers like 6 and 12 have close divisors (proved by norm_num). Intuition: most integers are 'lumpy' with clustered divisors.

sections.title: Part 5: Erdős's Retracted Claim
sections.summary: Historical notes on Erdős's 1964 flawed proof, the 1979 retraction with Hall, and Maier-Tenenbaum's 1984 vindication.

sections.title: Part 6: Proof Techniques
sections.summary: Placeholder axioms for key proof methods: divisor distribution theory, Erdős-Kac connection, probabilistic arguments, and moment calculations.

sections.title: Part 7: Related Problems
sections.summary: Connections to related Erdős problems #449 (divisor ratios), #884 (divisor gaps), and Guy's Problem E3.

sections.title: Part 8: The Prize
sections.summary: Historical notes on the $250 prize and Tenenbaum's reported $650 payment.

sections.title: Part 9: Summary
sections.summary: Proved erdos_144_status: both basic and strong versions hold (from Maier-Tenenbaum axioms). Problem SOLVED.

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #144 was SOLVED by Maier and Tenenbaum in 1984. The density of integers with close divisors (d₁ < d₂ < 2d₁) equals 1, and this holds for any c > 1. The refined version reveals a phase transition at β* = log 3 - 1.
conclusion.implications: The result demonstrates that 'generic' integers have divisors that cluster together, a manifestation of probabilistic number theory. The phase transition provides a precise characterization of how close divisors can be for almost all integers.
openQuestions: What is the exact rate of convergence to density 1?
Can the techniques extend to other divisor proximity questions?
What happens at the critical threshold β = log 3 - 1?
